Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<>>: $API <<>>: $CODE <<>>: $EXPLANATION. Question: Reading from a file?: :Please help me to do such a thing, let's say we have a text file, test.txt, about similar to this:hello hello hellohttp://stackoverflow.comThe first line of text, and the second link enclosed in the . I am printing the contents of the file as follows: if(myName.equals(name)){ InputStreamReader reader = null; try{ File file = new File("C:\\Users\\ваня\\Desktop\\asksearch\\" + list[i]); reader = new InputStreamReader(new FileInputStream(file), "UTF-8"); int b; PrintWriter wr = response.getWriter(); wr.print(""); wr.print(""); wr.print("HelloWorld"); wr.print(""); wr.print(""); wr.write("
"); while((b = reader.read()) != -1) { wr.write((char) b ); } wr.write("
"); wr.write("
"); wr.print(""); wr.print(""); wr.close(); }Just a piece of code:while((b = reader.read()) != -1) { writer.write((char) b);}You want to display, the first line of the file itself, and the second line of the file separatelyPrintWriter writer = response.getWriter();writer.print("");writer.print("");writer.print("HelloWorld");writer.print("");writer.write("
");// then the first linewriter.write("
");writer.write("
");// then the second linewriter.write("
");writer.print("");writer.print(""); Please using this api: PrintWriter.write. Answer: <<>>: PrintWriter.write <<>>: ```java PrintWriter writer = response.getWriter(); writer.print(""); writer.print(""); writer.print("HelloWorld"); writer.print(""); writer.write("
"); BufferedReader reader = new BufferedReader(new FileReader("C:\\Users\\ваня\\Desktop\\asksearch\\" + list[i])); String line = reader.readLine(); // read the first line writer.write(line); writer.write("
"); writer.write("
"); line = reader.readLine(); // read the second line writer.write(line); writer.write("
"); reader.close(); writer.print(""); writer.print(""); ``` <<>>: The code reads the first line of the file using BufferedReader's readLine() method and writes it to the response using PrintWriter's write() method. It does the same for the second line. The readLine() method returns null if there are no more lines to read. Note: The BufferedReader should be closed after you're done with it to free up system resources.
